questions.question: They .......................... have left in the morning. (possibility)
questions.description: Might indicates possibility. Will indicates certainty.

questions.question: Since the surgery, he .................................. walk again. (ability)
questions.description: Can shows general ability. Be able to is used to talk about being able to do something on a specific occasion.

questions.question: He suggested that I ........................... accept the offer. (obligation)
questions.description: We use should to make suggestions.

questions.question: You ............................... lied to him.
questions.description: Ought is followed by a to-infinitive.

questions.question: You .................................. told him about my accident. (lack of necessity)
............................ I help you with this? (Offer)
questions.description: Should is used to make offers.

questions.question: He ............................... watch a lot of movies when he was younger. (past habit)
questions.description: Would is used to talk about past habits.

questions.question: I think you ............................. find another job. (suggestion)
You ..................................... invited her to the party. (lack of obligation)
You ...................................... start now.
questions.description: All of these are possible here. Had better is more emphatic.

questions.question: He left late for the train station. He ................................. have missed the train.
questions.description: Both could and might can express possibility in affirmative sentences.

questions.question: If I were you, I ................................. apologize for something I didn't do.
